- **xero\_tenant\_id** ( `string`, required) Unique identifier for the Xero tenant. Required for accessing the relevant account data.
- **start\_date\_filter** ( `string`, optional) Filter the report by the starting date, formatted as YYYY-MM-DD. For example, 2021-02-01.
- **end\_date\_filter** ( `string`, optional) Filter the report by the end date, formatted as YYYY-MM-DD, e.g., 2021-02-28.

## XeroApi.RetrieveSpecificReport [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/mcp-servers/productivity/xero-api\#xeroapiretrievespecificreport)

See Example

Retrieve a specific report using a ReportID.

**Parameters**

- **report\_id** ( `string`, required) Unique identifier for a specific report to be retrieved.
- **xero\_tenant\_id** ( `string`, required) Xero identifier for the Tenant. This is required to specify which tenant’s data is being accessed.

## XeroApi.GetBudgetSummaryReport [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/mcp-servers/productivity/xero-api\#xeroapigetbudgetsummaryreport)

See Example

Retrieves the budget summary report from Xero.

**Parameters**

- **xero\_tenant\_identifier** ( `string`, required) The unique Xero identifier for the tenant, required for authentication and data retrieval.
- **report\_date** ( `string`, optional) The specific date for the budget summary report in YYYY-MM-DD format, e.g., 2018-03-31.
- **number\_of\_periods\_to\_compare** ( `integer`, optional) The number of periods for comparison, must be an integer between 1 and 12.
- **comparison\_timeframe** ( `integer`, optional) Specify the period size for comparison: 1 for month, 3 for quarter, or 12 for year.

## XeroApi.RetrieveExecutiveSummaryReport [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/mcp-servers/productivity/xero-api\#xeroapiretrieveexecutivesummaryreport)

See Example

Retrieve an executive summary report for financial insights.

**Parameters**

- **xero\_tenant\_identifier** ( `string`, required) The Xero identifier for the tenant. Required to specify which tenant’s data should be retrieved.
- **report\_date** ( `string`, optional) The date for the Bank Summary report in the format YYYY-MM-DD (e.g., 2018-03-31).

## XeroApi.RetrieveUniqueReportsList [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/mcp-servers/productivity/xero-api\#xeroapiretrieveuniquereportslist)

See Example

Retrieve a list of unique reports from Xero.

**Parameters**

- **xero\_tenant\_id** ( `string`, required) The unique identifier for the Xero tenant to retrieve reports for.

## XeroApi.GetProfitAndLossReport [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/mcp-servers/productivity/xero-api\#xeroapigetprofitandlossreport)

See Example

Retrieve profit and loss report from Xero.

**Parameters**

- **tenant\_identifier** ( `string`, required) The Xero identifier for the tenant. Required to specify which tenant’s data to access.
- **from\_date** ( `string`, optional) Filter the report by the starting date in YYYY-MM-DD format, e.g., 2021-02-01.
- **end\_date** ( `string`, optional) Filter by the end date of the report in YYYY-MM-DD format, e.g., 2021-02-28.
- **number\_of\_comparison\_periods** ( `integer`, optional) The number of periods to compare, must be an integer between 1 and 12.
- **comparison\_timeframe** ( `string`, optional) The period size to compare to for the report. Options are MONTH, QUARTER, or YEAR.
- **tracking\_category\_id** ( `string`, optional) The first tracking category ID for the Profit and Loss report filter. Expect a string representing the tracking category identifier.
- **secondary\_tracking\_category\_id** ( `string`, optional) The ID of the second tracking category for the Profit and Loss report.
- **tracking\_option\_1\_id** ( `string`, optional) The identifier for the first tracking option in the Profit and Loss report.
- **tracking\_option\_id\_2** ( `string`, optional) The second tracking option identifier for filtering the Profit and Loss report.
- **return\_standard\_layout** ( `boolean`, optional) Set to true to return the Profit and Loss report in the standard layout.
- **return\_cash\_basis\_only** ( `boolean`, optional) Specify true to return the Profit and Loss report on a cash only basis.

## XeroApi.GetTrialBalanceReport [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/mcp-servers/productivity/xero-api\#xeroapigettrialbalancereport)

See Example

Fetches the trial balance report from Xero.

**Parameters**

- **tenant\_identifier** ( `string`, required) The unique identifier for the Xero tenant to retrieve the trial balance report for.
- **report\_date** ( `string`, optional) The specific date for the Trial Balance report in YYYY-MM-DD format.
- **return\_cash\_basis\_only** ( `boolean`, optional) Set to true to return the trial balance report on a cash-only basis, false for accrual.

## XeroApi.SetFinancialSetup [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/mcp-servers/productivity/xero-api\#xeroapisetfinancialsetup)

See Example

Sets up the financial chart of accounts and conversion details.

**Parameters**

- **xero\_tenant\_identifier** ( `string`, required) Xero tenant ID required to identify the specific tenant for the request.
- **financial\_setup\_details** ( `json`, required) JSON object containing accounts, conversion balances, and a conversion date for setting up the financial chart in Xero.
- **idempotency\_key** ( `string`, optional) A unique string up to 128 characters to safely retry requests without duplicating processing.

## XeroApi.RetrieveTaxRates [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/mcp-servers/productivity/xero-api\#xeroapiretrievetaxrates)

Retrieve tax rates from Xero.

**Parameters**

- **xero\_tenant\_id** ( `string`, required) A unique identifier for the Xero tenant. This is required to access tenant-specific data.
- **filter\_by\_element** ( `string`, optional) Apply a filter to the tax rates by specifying an element condition (e.g. ‘Status==“ACTIVE”’).
- **order\_by\_element** ( `string`, optional) Specify the element to order the tax rates by. Provide any valid field or attribute name.

## Cursor IDE Integration
[Skip to Content](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor#nextra-skip-nav)

[Reference](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references "Reference") Arcade MCP [Python](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview "Python") [Clients](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop "Clients") Cursor

Copy page

# Cursor IDE

Cursor is an AI-powered IDE that supports MCP servers. This guide will help you integrate your Arcade MCP server with Cursor for enhanced development capabilities.

## Prerequisites [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#prerequisites)

- Cursor IDE installed
- Python 3.10+ installed
- `arcade-mcp` package installed ( `pip install arcade-mcp`)

## Configuration [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#configuration)

Cursor reads MCP server configurations from its settings. You can configure MCP servers through:

1. Cursor Settings UI
2. Configuration file
3. Workspace settings

## Basic setup [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#basic-setup)

### Method 1: Settings UI [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#method-1-settings-ui)

1. Open Cursor Settings ( `Cmd/Ctrl + Shift + J`)
2. Search for “MCP” or “Model Context Protocol”
3. Add a new server configuration:
   - **Name**: `arcade-tools`
   - **Command**: `python -m arcade_mcp stdio`
   - **Working Directory**: `/path/to/your/project`

### Method 2: Configuration file [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#method-2-configuration-file)

Add to your Cursor configuration:

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "mcp.servers": {
    "arcade-tools": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["-m", "arcade_mcp", "stdio"],
      "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",
      "env": {
        "PYTHONPATH": "${workspaceFolder}"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

### Method 3: Workspace settings [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#method-3-workspace-settings)

Create `.cursor/settings.json` in your workspace:

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "mcp.servers": {
    "project-tools": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["-m", "arcade_mcp", "stdio", "--debug"],
      "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",
      "env": {
        "ARCADE_API_KEY": "${env:ARCADE_API_KEY}"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

## Development workflow [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#development-workflow)

### Hot reload setup [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#hot-reload-setup)

For active development with automatic reload:

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "mcp.servers": {
    "dev-tools": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["-m", "arcade_mcp", "--reload", "--debug"],
      "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",
      "env": {
        "PYTHONPATH": "${workspaceFolder}"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

### Virtual environment [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#virtual-environment)

Use a project-specific virtual environment:

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "mcp.servers": {
    "project-tools": {
      "command": "${workspaceFolder}/venv/bin/python",
      "args": ["-m", "arcade_mcp", "stdio"],
      "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}"
    }
  }
}
```

### Multiple tool sets [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#multiple-tool-sets)

Configure different tool sets for different purposes:

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "mcp.servers": {
    "github-tools": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["-m", "arcade_mcp", "stdio", "--tool-package", "github"],
      "env": {
        "GITHUB_TOKEN": "${env:GITHUB_TOKEN}"
      }
    },
    "database-tools": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["-m", "arcade_mcp", "stdio"],
      "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}/db_tools",
      "env": {
        "DATABASE_URL": "${env:DATABASE_URL}"
      }
    },
    "api-tools": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["-m", "arcade_mcp", "stdio"],
      "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}/api_tools"
    }
  }
}
```

## Integration features [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#integration-features)

### Inline tool usage [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#inline-tool-usage)

Use tools directly in your code comments:

Python

```nextra-code

# @mcp use arcade-tools.greet name="World"
# Result will appear here

def process_data(data):
    # @mcp use database-tools.query sql="SELECT * FROM users"
    pass
```

### Tool discovery [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#tool-discovery)

View available tools in Cursor:

1. Open Command Palette ( `Cmd/Ctrl + Shift + P`)
2. Type “MCP: List Tools”
3. Select your server to see available tools

### Tool documentation [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#tool-documentation)

Access tool documentation:

1. Hover over tool usage in code
2. Use `Cmd/Ctrl + Click` on tool names
3. View in the MCP panel

## Advanced configuration [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#advanced-configuration)

### Environment-specific settings [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#environment-specific-settings)

Use different configurations per environment:

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "mcp.servers": {
    "tools-dev": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["-m", "arcade_mcp", "stdio", "--env-file", ".env.dev"],
      "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",
      "when": "${config:environment} == 'development'"
    },
    "tools-prod": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["-m", "arcade_mcp", "stdio", "--env-file", ".env.prod"],
      "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",
      "when": "${config:environment} == 'production'"
    }
  }
}
```

### Task integration [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#task-integration)

Create tasks for MCP server management:

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "version": "2.0.0",
  "tasks": [\
    {\
      "label": "Start MCP Server",\
      "type": "shell",\
      "command": "python -m arcade_mcp --reload --debug",\
      "problemMatcher": [],\
      "isBackground": true\
    },\
    {\
      "label": "Test Tools",\
      "type": "shell",\
      "command": "python -m arcade_mcp --tool-package ${input:package} --debug",\
      "problemMatcher": []\
    }\
  ],
  "inputs": [\
    {\
      "id": "package",\
      "type": "promptString",\
      "description": "Tool package name"\
    }\
  ]
}
```

### Debugging tools [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#debugging-tools)

Debug your tools with Cursor’s debugger:

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [\
    {\
      "name": "Debug MCP Tools",\
      "type": "python",\
      "request": "launch",\
      "module": "arcade_mcp",\
      "args": ["--debug", "--reload"],\
      "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",\
      "env": {\
        "PYTHONPATH": "${workspaceFolder}"\
      }\
    }\
  ]
}
```

## Best practices [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#best-practices)

### Project structure [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#project-structure)

Organize your MCPtools effectively:

PLAINTEXT

```nextra-code

my-project/
├── .cursor/
│   └── settings.json    # Cursor-specific settings
├── .env                 # Environment variables
├── .env.example         # Example environment file
├── tools/
│   ├── __init__.py
│   ├── data_tools.py    # Data processing tools
│   ├── api_tools.py     # API interaction tools
│   └── utils.py         # Utility tools
├── requirements.txt
└── README.md
```

### Tool development tips [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#tool-development-tips)

1. **Use type hints**: Enable better IDE support

Python

```nextra-code

from typing import Annotated

@tool
def process(
    data: Annotated[str, "Input data to process"],
    format: Annotated[str, "Output format"] = "json"
) -> Annotated[dict, "Processed data"]:
    """Process data in the specified format."""
    pass
```

2. **Provide clear descriptions**: Help Cursor understand tool usage
3. **Handle errors gracefully**: Return helpful error messages
4. **Use logging**: Enable debug mode for troubleshooting
5. **Test incrementally**: Use Cursor’s integrated terminal

### Performance optimization [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#performance-optimization)

1. **Lazy loading**: Import heavy dependencies inside tools
2. **Cache results**: Use caching for expensive operations
3. **Async support**: Use async tools for I/O operations
4. **Resource management**: Clean up resources properly

## Troubleshooting [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#troubleshooting)

### Common issues [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#common-issues)

#### Server not starting [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#server-not-starting)

1. Check Python path and virtual environment
2. Verify `arcade-mcp` installation
3. Enable debug logging to see errors
4. Check for import errors in tool files

#### Permission errors [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#permission-errors)

1. Ensure proper file permissions
2. Check working directory access
3. Verify environment variable access

#### Connection issues [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#connection-issues)

1. Restart Cursor after configuration changes
2. Check for conflicting MCP servers
3. Verify stdio transport is working

### Debugging steps [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#debugging-steps)

1. Enable debug mode in your configuration
2. Check Cursor’s output panel for MCP logs
3. Test tools using the command line first
4. Use Cursor’s Developer Tools for detailed logs

## Example: Complete setup [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/cursor\#example-complete-setup)

Here’s a full example of setting up a Cursor workspace with MCP:

1. **Create workspace structure**:

PLAINTEXT

```nextra-code

my-workspace/
├── .cursor/
│   └── settings.json
├── .vscode/
│   └── tasks.json
├── tools/
│   └── my_tools.py
└── pyproject.toml
```

2. **Configure `.cursor/settings.json`**:

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "mcp.servers": {
    "workspace-tools": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["-m", "arcade_mcp", "stdio", "--debug"],
      "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",
      "env": {
        "PYTHONPATH": "${workspaceFolder}"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

3. **Create `tools/my_tools.py`**:

Python

```nextra-code

from arcade_mcp_server import tool
from typing import Annotated
import json

@tool
async def format_json(
    data: Annotated[str, "JSON string to format"]
) -> Annotated[str, "Formatted JSON"]:
    """Format JSON data with proper indentation."""
    parsed = json.loads(data)
    return json.dumps(parsed, indent=2)

@tool
def analyze_code(
    file_path: Annotated[str, "Path to analyze"]
) -> Annotated[dict, "Analysis results"]:
    """Analyze Python code quality."""
    # Implementation here
    pass
```

4. **Restart Cursor and start using your tools!**

## Claude Desktop Setup
[Skip to Content](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop#nextra-skip-nav)

[Reference](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references "Reference") Arcade MCP [Python](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview "Python") ClientsClaude Desktop

Copy page

# Claude Desktop

Claude Desktop supports MCP servers through its configuration system. This guide will help you set up your Arcade MCP server with Claude Desktop.

## Prerequisites [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#prerequisites)

- Claude Desktop installed
- Python 3.10+ installed
- `arcade-mcp` package installed ( `pip install arcade-mcp`)

## Quick setup with Arcade CLI [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#quick-setup-with-arcade-cli)

The easiest way to configure Claude Desktop is with the `arcade configure` command:

Terminal

```nextra-code

# Install Arcade CLI
uv pip install arcade-mcp

# Create a new server (optional, if you don't have one yet)
arcade new my_server
cd my_server

# Configure Claude Desktop to use your local server
arcade configure claude --from-local
```

This automatically updates your Claude Desktop configuration file with the correct settings.

## Manual configuration [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#manual-configuration)

Claude Desktop reads MCP server configurations from its settings file. The location varies by platform:

- **macOS**: `~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`
- **Windows**: `%APPDATA%\Claude\claude_desktop_config.json`
- **Linux**: `~/.config/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`

## Basic setup [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#basic-setup)

### 1\. Create or edit configuration [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#1-create-or-edit-configuration)

Add your MCP server to the configuration file:

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "arcade-tools": {
      "command": "arcade",
      "args": ["mcp", "stdio"],
      "cwd": "/path/to/your/project"
    }
  }
}
```

> **Note:** If you don’t have the Arcade CLI installed globally, you can use the module directly:
>
> JSON
>
> ```nextra-code
>
> {
>   "mcpServers": {
>     "arcade-tools": {
>       "command": "arcade",
>       "args": ["-m", "arcade_mcp_server", "stdio"],
>       "cwd": "/path/to/your/project"
>     }
>   }
> }
> ```

### 2\. Multiple servers [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#2-multiple-servers)

You can configure multiple MCP servers:

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "github-tools": {
      "command": "arcade",
      "args": ["mcp", "stdio", "--tool-package", "github"],
      "env": {
        "GITHUB_TOKEN": "your-github-token"
      }
    },
    "slack-tools": {
      "command": "arcade",
      "args": ["mcp", "stdio", "--tool-package", "slack"],
      "env": {
        "SLACK_BOT_TOKEN": "your-slack-token"
      }
    },
    "custom-tools": {
      "command": "arcade",
      "args": ["mcp", "stdio"],
      "cwd": "/path/to/custom/tools"
    }
  }
}
```

## Troubleshooting [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#troubleshooting)

### Common issues [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#common-issues)

#### Server not starting [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#server-not-starting)

1. Check the command path is correct
2. Verify `arcade` is in your PATH (or use full path to `arcade` binary)
3. Ensure `arcade-mcp` is installed ( `uv pip install arcade-mcp`)
4. Check file permissions on the working directory

#### Tools not available [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#tools-not-available)

1. Verify tools are properly decorated with `@tool`
2. Check the working directory is correct
3. Enable debug mode to see tool discovery logs
4. Ensure no import errors in your tool files

#### Authentication errors [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#authentication-errors)

1. Verify environment variables are set correctly
2. Check API keys and tokens are valid
3. Ensure proper escaping of special characters in JSON

### Viewing logs [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#viewing-logs)

When using stdio transport, logs are sent to stderr. To capture logs:

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "my-tools": {
      "command": "arcade",
      "args": ["mcp", "stdio", "--debug"],
      "cwd": "/path/to/project",
      "stderr": "/tmp/arcade-mcp.log"
    }
  }
}
```

### Testing your configuration [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#testing-your-configuration)

1. Save your configuration file
2. Restart Claude Desktop
3. Look for your server in Claude’s interface
4. Try using a simple tool to verify it’s working

## Best practices [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#best-practices)

1. **Use virtual environments**: Isolate dependencies for each MCP server
2. **Manage secrets securely**: Use environment files or secret management tools
3. **Enable debug logging**: During development to troubleshoot issues
4. **Organize tools**: Group related tools in separate servers
5. **Document your tools**: Use clear descriptions and type annotations

## Example: Complete setup [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#example-complete-setup)

### Using Arcade CLI (recommended) [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#using-arcade-cli-recommended)

The fastest way to get started:

Terminal

```nextra-code

# Create a new server with example tools
arcade new my_server
cd my_server

# Configure Claude Desktop
arcade configure claude --from-local

# Restart Claude Desktop and your tools will be available!
```

### Manual setup [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop\#manual-setup)

If you prefer to set up manually:

1. Create your project structure:

PLAINTEXT

```nextra-code

my-mcp-project/
├── .env
├── requirements.txt
└── tools.py
```

2. Create `tools.py`:

Python

```nextra-code

from arcade_mcp_server import tool
from typing import Annotated

@tool
def greet(name: Annotated[str, "Name to greet"]) -> str:
    """Greet someone by name."""
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

@tool
def calculate(
    expression: Annotated[str, "Math expression"]
) -> Annotated[float, "Result"]:
    """Calculate a mathematical expression."""
    return eval(expression, {"__builtins__": {}}, {})
```

3. Configure Claude Desktop:

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "my-project": {
      "command": "arcade",
      "args": ["mcp", "stdio", "--debug"],
      "cwd": "/path/to/my-mcp-project"
    }
  }
}
```

4. Restart Claude Desktop and your tools will be available!

## MCP Inspector
[Skip to Content](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector#nextra-skip-nav)

[Reference](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references "Reference") Arcade MCP [Python](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview "Python") [Clients](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/claude-desktop "Clients") MCP Inspector

# MCP Inspector

The MCP Inspector is a powerful debugging and testing tool for MCP servers. It provides a web-based interface to interact with your Arcade MCP server, test tools, and monitor protocol messages.

## Installation [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#installation)

Install the MCP Inspector globally:

Terminal

```nextra-code

npm install -g @modelcontextprotocol/inspector
```

Or use npx to run without installing:

Terminal

```nextra-code

npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector
```

## Basic usage [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#basic-usage)

### Connecting to HTTP servers [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#connecting-to-http-servers)

For MCP servers running over HTTP:

Terminal

```nextra-code

# Start your MCP server
uv run server.py

# In another terminal, start the inspector
mcp-inspector http://localhost:8000/mcp
```

### Connecting to stdio servers [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#connecting-to-stdio-servers)

For stdio-based servers:

Terminal

```nextra-code

# Start the inspector with your server command
mcp-inspector "uv run server.py stdio"

# With additional project directory
mcp-inspector --cwd /path/to/project "uv run server.py stdio"
```

## Inspector features [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#inspector-features)

### Tool Explorer [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#tool-explorer)

The Tool Explorer shows all available tools with:

- Tool names and descriptions
- Parameter schemas
- Return type information
- Example invocations

### Interactive testing [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#interactive-testing)

Test tools directly from the interface:

1. Select a tool from the explorer
2. Fill in parameter values
3. Click “Execute” to run the tool
4. View results and execution time

### Protocol Monitor [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#protocol-monitor)

Monitor all MCP protocol messages:

- Request/response pairs
- Message timing
- Protocol errors
- Raw JSON data

### Resource Browser [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#resource-browser)

If your server provides resources:

- Browse available resources
- View resource contents
- Test resource operations

### Prompt templates [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#prompt-templates)

Test prompt templates if supported:

- View available prompts
- Fill template parameters
- Preview rendered prompts

## Advanced usage [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#advanced-usage)

### Custom environment [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#custom-environment)

Pass environment variables to your server:

Terminal

```nextra-code

# Using env command
env ARCADE_API_KEY=your-key mcp-inspector "uv run server.py stdio"

# Using inspector's env option
mcp-inspector --env ARCADE_API_KEY=your-key "uv run server.py stdio"
```

### Working directory [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#working-directory)

Set the working directory for your server:

Terminal

```nextra-code

mcp-inspector --cwd /path/to/project "uv run server.py stdio"
```

### Debug mode [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#debug-mode)

Enable verbose logging:

Terminal

```nextra-code

# Debug the inspector
mcp-inspector --debug "uv run server.py stdio"

# Server debug logging is configured in your server.py
# app = MCPApp(name="my_server", version="1.0.0", log_level="DEBUG")
```

## Testing workflows [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#testing-workflows)

### Tool development [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#tool-development)

1. **Configure your server with hot reload**:

Python

```nextra-code

# In your server.py
if __name__ == "__main__":
    transport = sys.argv[1] if len(sys.argv) > 1 else "http"
    app.run(transport=transport, host="127.0.0.1", port=8000, reload=True)
```

Then run:

Terminal

```nextra-code

uv run server.py
```

2. **Connect the inspector**:

Terminal

```nextra-code

mcp-inspector http://localhost:8000/mcp
```

3. **Develop and test**:
   - Modify your tool code
   - Server auto-reloads
   - Test immediately in inspector

### Performance testing [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#performance-testing)

Use the inspector to measure tool performance:

1. Enable timing in the Protocol Monitor
2. Execute tools multiple times
3. Analyze response times
4. Identify bottlenecks

### Error debugging [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#error-debugging)

Debug tool errors effectively:

1. Enable debug mode on your server
2. Execute the failing tool
3. Check Protocol Monitor for error details
4. View server logs in terminal

## Integration testing [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#integration-testing)

### Test suites [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#test-suites)

Create test suites using the inspector:

JavaScript

```nextra-code

// test-tools.js
const tests = [\
    {\
        tool: "greet",\
        params: { name: "World" },\
        expected: "Hello, World!"\
    },\
    {\
        tool: "calculate",\
        params: { expression: "2 + 2" },\
        expected: 4\
    }\
];

// Run tests via inspector API
```

### Automated testing [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#automated-testing)

Combine with testing frameworks:

Python

```nextra-code

# test_mcp_tools.py
import subprocess
import json
import pytest

def test_tool_via_inspector():
    # Start server
    server = subprocess.Popen(
        ["python", "-m", "arcade_mcp_server"],
        stdout=subprocess.PIPE
    )

    # Use inspector's API to test tools
    # ...
```

## Best practices [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#best-practices)

### Development setup [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#development-setup)

1. **Use split terminal**:
   - Terminal 1: MCP server with reload
   - Terminal 2: Inspector
   - Terminal 3: Code editor
2. **Enable all debugging**:


Python

```nextra-code

# In server.py
app = MCPApp(name="my_server", version="1.0.0", log_level="DEBUG")

# Run with reload
app.run(transport="http", host="127.0.0.1", port=8000, reload=True)
```

Then run with environment file:

Terminal

```nextra-code

uv run server.py
```

3. **Save test cases**:
   - Export successful tool calls
   - Build regression test suite
   - Document edge cases

### Production testing [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#production-testing)

1. **Test against production config**:

Terminal

```nextra-code

mcp-inspector "uv run server.py stdio"
```

2. **Verify security**:
   - Test with limited permissions
   - Verify API key handling
   - Check error messages don’t leak secrets
3. **Load testing**:
   - Execute tools rapidly
   - Monitor memory usage
   - Check for resource leaks

## Troubleshooting [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#troubleshooting)

### Common issues [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#common-issues)

#### Server not starting [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#server-not-starting)

1. Verify server is running
2. Check correct URL/command
3. Ensure ports aren’t blocked
4. Try with `--debug` flag

#### Protocol error [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#protocol-error)

1. Ensure server implements MCP correctly
2. Check for version compatibility
3. Review server logs
4. Verify transport type

#### Tool not found [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#tool-not-found)

1. Verify tool is decorated with `@tool`
2. Check tool discovery in server
3. Ensure no import errors
4. Restart server and inspector

#### Parameter validation failed [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#parameter-validation-failed)

1. Check parameter types match schema
2. Verify required parameters
3. Test with simpler values
4. Review tool documentation

## Examples [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#examples)

### Quick test session [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#quick-test-session)

Terminal

```nextra-code

# 1. Start a simple MCP server
cat > test_tools.py << 'EOF'
from arcade_mcp_server import tool
from typing import Annotated

@tool
def echo(message: Annotated[str, "Message to echo"]) -> str:
    """Echo the message back."""
    return message

@tool
def add(
    a: Annotated[int, "First number"],
    b: Annotated[int, "Second number"]
) -> Annotated[int, "Sum"]:
    """Add two numbers."""
    return a + b
EOF

# 2. Start inspector
mcp-inspector "uv run server.py stdio"

# 3. Test tools in the web interface
```

### HTTP server testing [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#http-server-testing)

Terminal

```nextra-code

# 1. Create an MCPApp server
cat > app.py << 'EOF'
from arcade_mcp_server import MCPApp
from typing import Annotated

app = MCPApp(name="test-server", version="1.0.0")

@app.tool
def get_time() -> Annotated[str, "Current time"]:
    """Get the current time."""
    from datetime import datetime
    return datetime.now().isoformat()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(port=9000, reload=True)
EOF

# 2. Run the server
python app.py

# 3. Connect inspector
mcp-inspector http://localhost:9000/mcp
```

### Debugging session [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/mcp-inspector\#debugging-session)

Terminal

```nextra-code

# 1. Enable all debugging
export DEBUG=*
export MCP_DEBUG=true

# 2. Start server with verbose logging
# (configure log_level="DEBUG" in your server.py)
uv run server.py stdio 2>server.log

# 3. Start inspector with debugging
mcp-inspector --debug "uv run server.py stdio"
```

## MCP Python Errors
[Skip to Content](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors#nextra-skip-nav)

[Reference](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references "Reference") Arcade MCP [Python](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview "Python") Errors

Copy page

# Errors

Domain-specific error types raised by the MCP server and components.

## `arcade_mcp_server.exceptions` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#arcade_mcp_serverexceptions)

MCP Exception Hierarchy

Provides domain-specific exceptions for better error handling and debugging.

### `MCPError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#mcperror)

**Bases:** `Exception`

Base error for all MCP-related exceptions.

### `MCPRuntimeError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#mcpruntimeerror)

**Bases:** `MCPError`

Runtime error for all MCP-related exceptions.

### `MCPContextError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#mcpcontexterror)

**Bases:** `MCPError`

Error in context management.

### `ServerError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#servererror)

**Bases:** `MCPRuntimeError`

Error in server operations.

### `AuthorizationError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#authorizationerror)

**Bases:** `MCPContextError`

Authorization failure.

### `LifespanError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#lifespanerror)

**Bases:** `ServerError`

Error in lifespan management.

### `NotFoundError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#notfounderror)

**Bases:** `MCPContextError`

Requested entity not found.

### `PromptError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#prompterror)

**Bases:** `MCPContextError`

Error in prompt management.

### `ProtocolError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#protocolerror)

**Bases:** `MCPRuntimeError`

Error in MCP protocol handling.

### `RequestError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#requesterror)

**Bases:** `ServerError`

Error in request processing from client to server.

### `ResourceError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#resourceerror)

**Bases:** `MCPContextError`

Error in resource management.

### `ResponseError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#responseerror)

**Bases:** `ServerError`

Error in request processing from server to client.

### `ServerRequestError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#serverrequesterror)

**Bases:** `RequestError`

Error in sending request from server to client initiated by the server.

### `SessionError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#sessionerror)

**Bases:** `ServerError`

Error in session management.

### `TransportError` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#transporterror)

**Bases:** `MCPRuntimeError`

Error in transport layer (stdio, HTTP, etc).

## Examples [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#examples)

### Raising exceptions for common error scenarios [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/errors\#raising-exceptions-for-common-error-scenarios)

Python

```nextra-code

from arcade_mcp_server.exceptions import (
    MCPError,
    NotFoundError,
    ValidationError,
    ToolError,
)

# Raising a not-found when a resource is missing
async def read_resource_or_fail(uri: str) -> str:
    if not await exists(uri):
        raise NotFoundError(f"Resource not found: {uri}")
    return await read(uri)

# Validating input
def validate_age(age: int) -> None:
    if age < 0:
        raise ValidationError("age must be non-negative")

# Handling tool execution errors in middleware or handlers
async def call_tool_safely(call):
    try:
        return await call()
    except ToolError as e:
        # Convert to an error result or re-raise
        raise MCPError(f"Tool failed: {e}")
```

# Visual Studio Code

While VSCode doesn’t have native MCP support yet, you can integrate Arcade MCP servers with VSCode through extensions and custom configurations. This guide shows various integration approaches.

## Prerequisites [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#prerequisites)

- Visual Studio Code installed
- Python 3.10+ installed
- `arcade-mcp` package installed ( `pip install arcade-mcp`)
- Python extension for VSCode

## Integration methods [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#integration-methods)

### Method 1: Terminal integration [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#method-1-terminal-integration)

Use VSCode’s integrated terminal to run MCP servers:

1. Open integrated terminal (\`Ctrl/Cmd + “)
2. Start your MCP server:

Terminal

```nextra-code

uv run server.py
```

3. Use split terminals for multiple servers

### Method 2: Task runner [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#method-2-task-runner)

Create tasks to manage MCP servers:

#### Create `.vscode/tasks.json`: [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#create-vscodetasksjson)

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "version": "2.0.0",
  "tasks": [\
    {\
      "label": "Start MCP Server",\
      "type": "shell",\
      "command": "python",\
      "args": ["-m", "arcade_mcp_server", "--reload", "--debug"],\
      "isBackground": true,\
      "problemMatcher": {\
        "pattern": {\
          "regexp": "^(ERROR|WARNING):\\s+(.+)$",\
          "severity": 1,\
          "message": 2\
        },\
        "background": {\
          "activeOnStart": true,\
          "beginsPattern": "^Starting.*",\
          "endsPattern": "^.*Server ready.*"\
        }\
      },\
      "presentation": {\
        "reveal": "always",\
        "panel": "dedicated"\
      }\
    },\
    {\
      "label": "Start MCP (HTTP)",\
      "type": "shell",\
      "command": "python",\
      "args": [\
        "-m", "arcade_mcp_server",\
        "--host", "0.0.0.0",\
        "--port", "8000",\
        "--reload"\
      ],\
      "isBackground": true,\
      "problemMatcher": []\
    },\
    {\
      "label": "Test Tools",\
      "type": "shell",\
      "command": "python",\
      "args": ["${workspaceFolder}/test_tools.py"],\
      "problemMatcher": "$python"\
    }\
  ]
}
```

Run tasks via:

- Command Palette: `Tasks: Run Task`
- Terminal menu: `Terminal > Run Task`

### Method 3: Launch configurations [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#method-3-launch-configurations)

Debug your MCPtools with VSCode’s debugger:

#### Create `.vscode/launch.json`: [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#create-vscodelaunchjson)

JSON

```nextra-code

{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [\
    {\
      "name": "Debug MCP Server",\
      "type": "python",\
      "request": "launch",\
      "module": "arcade_mcp_server",\
      "args": ["--debug", "--reload"],\
      "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",\
      "env": {\
        "PYTHONPATH": "${workspaceFolder}",\
        "ARCADE_API_KEY": "${env:ARCADE_API_KEY}"\
      },\
      "console": "integratedTerminal"\
    },\
    {\
      "name": "Debug Specific Tool",\
      "type": "python",\
      "request": "launch",\
      "program": "${workspaceFolder}/tools/my_tool.py",\
      "args": ["--test"],\
      "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",\
      "console": "integratedTerminal"\
    },\
    {\
      "name": "Debug with Package",\
      "type": "python",\
      "request": "launch",\
      "module": "arcade_mcp_server",\
      "args": [\
        "--tool-package", "github",\
        "--debug"\
      ],\
      "env": {\
        "GITHUB_TOKEN": "${input:githubToken}"\
      }\
    }\
  ],
  "inputs": [\
    {\
      "id": "githubToken",\
      "type": "promptString",\
      "description": "Enter your GitHub token",\
      "password": true\
    }\
  ]
}
```

### Python test scripts [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#python-test-scripts)

Create test scripts for your tools:

Python

```nextra-code

# test_tools.py
import asyncio
from arcade_core.catalog import ToolCatalog

async def test_tools():
    # Import your tools
    from tools import my_tools

    # Create catalog
    catalog = ToolCatalog()
    catalog.add_tool(my_tools.greet, "test")

    # Test tool
    result = await catalog.call_tool(
        "test.greet",
        {"name": "Test"}
    )
    print(f"Result: {result}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(test_tools())
```

### Logging configuration [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#logging-configuration)

Enhanced logging for debugging:

Python

```nextra-code

# tools/__init__.py
import logging
from loguru import logger

# Configure loguru
logger.add(
    "debug.log",
    rotation="10 MB",
    level="DEBUG",
    format="{time} {level} {message}"
)

# Intercept standard logging
class InterceptHandler(logging.Handler):
    def emit(self, record):
        logger_opt = logger.opt(depth=6, exception=record.exc_info)
        logger_opt.log(record.levelname, record.getMessage())

logging.basicConfig(handlers=[InterceptHandler()], level=0)
```

## Best practices [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#best-practices)

1. **Use virtual environments**: Always work in isolated environments
2. **Version control settings**: Include `.vscode` in your repository
3. **Environment files**: Use `.env` files for secrets
4. **Consistent formatting**: Configure formatters and linters
5. **Test automation**: Set up test tasks and debug configs
6. **Documentation**: Keep README and docstrings updated
7. **Git hooks**: Use pre-commit for code quality

## Troubleshooting [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#troubleshooting)

### Common issues [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#common-issues)

#### Python interpreter not found [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#python-interpreter-not-found)

1. Select interpreter: `Cmd/Ctrl + Shift + P` \> “Python: Select Interpreter”
2. Ensure virtual environment is activated

#### Module import errors [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#module-import-errors)

1. Check PYTHONPATH in settings
2. Verify package installation
3. Restart VSCode

#### Debug breakpoints not working [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#debug-breakpoints-not-working)

1. Ensure you’re using the debug configuration
2. Check that debugpy is installed
3. Verify source maps are correct

#### Task execution fails [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/clients/visual-studio-code\#task-execution-fails)

1. Check task definition syntax
2. Verify working directory
3. Review terminal output for errors

## Python Middleware

[Reference](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references "Reference") Arcade MCP [Python](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview "Python") Middleware

Copy page

# Middleware

Middleware allows you to intercept and modify requests and responses at various stages of processing. Each handler receives the context and a `call_next` function to invoke the next handler in the chain.

## Base classes [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#base-classes)

### `Middleware` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#middleware)

**`arcade_mcp_server.middleware.base.Middleware`**

Base class for MCP middleware with typed handlers for each method.

Middleware can intercept and modify requests and responses at various stages of processing. Each handler receives the context and a `call_next` function to invoke the next handler in the chain.

#### Methods [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#methods)

##### `__call__` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#__call__)

Python

```nextra-code

async __call__(context, call_next)
```

Main entry point that orchestrates the middleware chain.

##### `on_call_tool` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#on_call_tool)

Python

```nextra-code

async on_call_tool(context, call_next)
```

Handle tool calls. Override to add tool-specific processing.

##### `on_get_prompt` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#on_get_prompt)

Python

```nextra-code

```

Handle prompt retrieval. Override to add prompt processing.

### `MiddlewareContext` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#middlewarecontext)

**`arcade_mcp_server.middleware.base.MiddlewareContext`**

Context passed through the middleware chain. Contains the message being processed and metadata about the request.

This is a dataclass that inherits from `Generic[T]`.

#### Methods [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#methods-1)

##### `copy` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#copy)

Python

```nextra-code

copy(**kwargs)
```

Create a copy with updated fields.

## Utility functions [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#utility-functions)

### `compose_middleware` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#compose_middleware)

**`arcade_mcp_server.middleware.base.compose_middleware(*middleware)`**

Compose multiple middleware into a single handler.

The middleware are applied in reverse order, so the first middleware in the list is the outermost (runs first on request, last on response).

## Built-in middleware [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#built-in-middleware)

### `LoggingMiddleware` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#loggingmiddleware)

**`arcade_mcp_server.middleware.logging.LoggingMiddleware`**

Middleware that logs all MCP messages and timing information.

Inherits from `Middleware`.

#### Methods [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#methods-2)


Initialize logging middleware.

**Parameters:**

| Name | Type | Description | Default |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| `log_level` | `str` | The log level to use for message logging | `'INFO'` |

### `ErrorHandlingMiddleware` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#errorhandlingmiddleware)

**`arcade_mcp_server.middleware.error_handling.ErrorHandlingMiddleware`**

Middleware that handles errors and converts them to appropriate responses.

Inherits from `Middleware`.

#### Methods [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#methods-3)

##### `__init__` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#__init__-1)

Python

```nextra-code

__init__(mask_error_details=True)
```

Initialize error handling middleware.

**Parameters:**

| Name | Type | Description | Default |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| `mask_error_details` | `bool` | Whether to mask error details in responses | `True` |

##### `on_call_tool` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#on_call_tool-1)

Python

```nextra-code

async on_call_tool(context, call_next)
```

##### `on_message` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#on_message-2)

```nextra-code

async on_message(context, call_next)
```

## Examples [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#examples)

### Creating custom middleware [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#creating-custom-middleware)

Python

```nextra-code

# Implement a custom middleware
from arcade_mcp_server.middleware.base import Middleware, MiddlewareContext

class TimingMiddleware(Middleware):
    async def __call__(self, context: MiddlewareContext, call_next):
        import time
        start = time.perf_counter()
        try:
            return await call_next(context)
        finally:
            elapsed_ms = (time.perf_counter() - start) * 1000
            # Attach timing info to context metadata
            context.metadata["elapsed_ms"] = round(elapsed_ms, 2)
```

### Composing middleware [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/middleware\#composing-middleware)

Python

```nextra-code

# Compose middleware and create a server
from arcade_mcp_server.middleware.base import compose_middleware
from arcade_mcp_server.middleware.logging import LoggingMiddleware
from arcade_mcp_server.middleware.error_handling import ErrorHandlingMiddleware
from arcade_mcp_server.server import MCPServer
from arcade_core.catalog import ToolCatalog

middleware = compose_middleware([\
    ErrorHandlingMiddleware(mask_error_details=False),\
    LoggingMiddleware(log_level="INFO"),\
    TimingMiddleware(),\
])

server = MCPServer(catalog=ToolCatalog(), middleware=[middleware])
```

# Server

Low-level server for hosting Arcade tools over MCP.

## `MCPServer` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/server\#mcpserver)

**`arcade_mcp_server.server.MCPServer`**

MCP Server with middleware and context support.

This server provides:

- Middleware chain for extensible request processing
- Context injection for tools
- Component managers for tools, resources, and prompts
- Bidirectional communication support to MCP clients

### Properties [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/server\#properties)

#### `prompts` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/server\#prompts)

Access the PromptManager for runtime prompt operations.

#### `resources` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/server\#resources)

Access the ResourceManager for runtime resource operations.

#### `tools` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/server\#tools)

Access the ToolManager for runtime tool operations.

### Methods [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/server\#methods)

### Examples [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/server\#examples)

#### Basic server with tool catalog and stdio transport [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/server\#basic-server-with-tool-catalog-and-stdio-transport)

Python

```nextra-code

import asyncio
from arcade_mcp_server.server import MCPServer
from arcade_core.catalog import ToolCatalog
from arcade_mcp_server.transports.stdio import StdioTransport

async def main():
    catalog = ToolCatalog()
    server = MCPServer(catalog=catalog, name="example", version="1.0.0")
    await server._start()
    try:
        # Run stdio transport loop
        transport = StdioTransport()
        await transport.run(server)
    finally:
        await server._stop()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())
```

#### Handling a single HTTP streamable connection [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/server\#handling-a-single-http-streamable-connection)

Python

```nextra-code

import asyncio
from arcade_mcp_server.server import MCPServer
from arcade_core.catalog import ToolCatalog
from arcade_mcp_server.transports.http_streamable import HTTPStreamableTransport

async def run_http():
    catalog = ToolCatalog()
    server = MCPServer(catalog=catalog)
    await server._start()
    try:
        transport = HTTPStreamableTransport(host="0.0.0.0", port=8000)
        await transport.run(server)
    finally:
        await server._stop()

asyncio.run(run_http())
```

# Arcade MCP (MCP Server SDK) - Python Overview

`arcade mcp` provides a clean, minimal API for building MCP servers programmatically. It handles tool collection, server configuration, and transport setup with a developer-friendly interface.

#### Basic Usage [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview\#basic-usage)

Python

```nextra-code

from arcade_mcp_server import MCPApp

app = MCPApp(name="my_server", version="1.0.0")

@app.tool
def greet(name: str) -> str:
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

app.run(host="127.0.0.1", port=8000)
```

#### Class Reference [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview\#class-reference)

### `MCPApp` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview\#mcpapp)

**`arcade_mcp_server.mcp_app.MCPApp`**

A FastAPI-like interface for building MCP servers.

The app collects tools and configuration, then lazily creates the server and transport when `run()` is called.

**Example:**

Python

```nextra-code

from arcade_mcp_server import MCPApp

app = MCPApp(name="my_server", version="1.0.0")

@app.tool
def greet(name: str) -> str:
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

# Runtime CRUD once you have a server bound to the app:
# app.server = mcp_server
# await app.tools.add(materialized_tool)
# await app.prompts.add(prompt, handler)
# await app.resources.add(resource)

app.run(host="127.0.0.1", port=8000)
```

#### Properties [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview\#properties)

##### `prompts` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview\#prompts)

Runtime prompts API: add/remove/list.

##### `resources` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview\#resources)

Runtime resources API: add/remove/list.

##### `tools` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview\#tools)

Runtime and build-time tools API: add/update/remove/list.

#### Methods [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview\#methods)

##### `__init__` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview\#__init__)

```nextra-code
    name='ArcadeMCP',
```

Initialize the MCP app.

**Parameters:**

| Name | Type | Description | Default |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |

| `title` | `str | None` | Server title for display | `None` |
| `instructions` | `str | None` | Server instructions | `None` |
| `log_level` | `str` | Logging level (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR) | `'INFO'` |
| `transport` | `TransportType` | Transport type (“http”) | `'http'` |
| `host` | `str` | Host for transport | `'127.0.0.1'` |
| `port` | `int` | Port for transport | `8000` |

| `**kwargs` | `Any` | Additional server configuration | `{}` |

#### Examples [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview\#examples)

Python

```nextra-code

# --- server.py ---
# Programmatic server creation with a simple tool and HTTP transport

from arcade_mcp_server import MCPApp

app = MCPApp(name="example_server", version="1.0.0")

@app.tool
def echo(text: str) -> str:
    return f"Echo: {text}"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    # Start an HTTP server (good for local development/testing)
    app.run(host="0.0.0.0", port=8000, reload=False, debug=True)
```

Terminal

```nextra-code

# then run the server
python server.py
```

## MCP Server Sharing
[Skip to Content](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/sharing#nextra-skip-nav)

[Reference](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references "Reference") Arcade MCP [Python](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview "Python") Sharing

Copy page

# Sharing your MCP server

Make your MCP server accessible to others by exposing it through a secure tunnel and registering it with Arcade. This allows remote users and services to interact with your tools without deploying to a cloud platform.

## Overview [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/sharing\#overview)

By default, your MCP server runs locally on `localhost:8000`. To share it:

1. Run your server with HTTP transport
2. Create a secure tunnel to expose it publicly
3. Register your server in Arcade
4. Share the tools with others

## Step 1: Run your server [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/sharing\#step-1-run-your-server)

First, start your MCP server with HTTP transport:

Terminal

```nextra-code

# Navigate to your server directory
cd my_server

# Run with HTTP transport (default)
uv run server.py
uv run server.py http
```

Your server will start on `http://localhost:8000`. Keep this terminal running.

## Step 2: Create a secure tunnel [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/sharing\#step-2-create-a-secure-tunnel)

Open a **separate terminal** and create a tunnel using one of these options:

### Option A: ngrok (recommended for getting started) [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/sharing\#option-a-ngrok-recommended-for-getting-started)

ngrok is easy to set up and works across all platforms.

**Install ngrok:**

Terminal

```nextra-code

# macOS
brew install ngrok

# Or download from https://ngrok.com/download
```

**Create a tunnel:**

Terminal

```nextra-code

ngrok http 8000
```

**Copy your URL:** Look for the “Forwarding” line in the ngrok output:

PLAINTEXT

```nextra-code

Forwarding  https://abc123.ngrok-free.app -> http://localhost:8000
```

Copy the `https://abc123.ngrok-free.app` URL - this is your public URL.

**Pros:**

- Quick setup, no account required for basic use
- Automatic HTTPS
- Web dashboard to inspect requests

**Cons:**

- Free tier URLs change on each restart
- May show interstitial page for free tier

### Option B: Cloudflare Tunnel [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/sharing\#option-b-cloudflare-tunnel)

Cloudflare Tunnel provides persistent URLs and advanced features.

**Install cloudflared:**

Terminal

```nextra-code

# macOS
brew install cloudflare/cloudflare/cloudflared

# Or download from https://developers.cloudflare.com/cloudflare-one/connections/connect-apps/install-and-setup/
```

**Create a tunnel:**

Terminal

```nextra-code

cloudflared tunnel --url http://localhost:8000
```

**Copy your URL:** Look for the “Your quick Tunnel has been created” message with your URL.

**Pros:**

- Free tier includes persistent URLs (with setup)
- Built-in DDoS protection
- Access control features

**Cons:**

- Requires Cloudflare account for persistent URLs
- More complex setup for advanced features

### Option C: Tailscale Funnel [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/sharing\#option-c-tailscale-funnel)

Tailscale Funnel is ideal for sharing within a team or organization.

**Install Tailscale:**

Terminal

```nextra-code

# macOS
brew install tailscale

# Or download from https://tailscale.com/download
```

**Authenticate:**

Terminal

```nextra-code

tailscale up
```

**Create a funnel:**

Terminal

```nextra-code

tailscale funnel 8000
```

**Get your URL:** Tailscale will display your funnel URL (e.g., `https://my-machine.tail-scale.ts.net`)

**Pros:**

- Persistent URLs tied to your machine
- Private by default (only shared with specified users)
- No bandwidth limits

**Cons:**

- Requires Tailscale account
- Best for team/organization use cases

## Step 3: Register your MCP server in Arcade [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/sharing\#step-3-register-your-mcp-server-in-arcade)

Once you have a public URL, register your MCP server in the Arcade dashboard to make it accessible through the Arcade API.

### Register your server [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/sharing\#register-your-server)

1. **Navigate to the MCP Servers page** in your Arcade dashboard
2. **Click “Add Server”**
3. **Fill in the registration form:**
   - **ID**: Choose a unique identifier (e.g., `my-mcp-server`)
   - **Server Type**: Select “HTTP/SSE”
   - **URL**: Enter your public tunnel URL from Step 2 with `/mcp` appended
     - Example: `https://abc123.ngrok-free.app/mcp`
     - Example: `https://my-tunnel.trycloudflare.com/mcp`
     - Example: `https://my-machine.tail-scale.ts.net/mcp`
   - **Secret**: Enter a secret for your server (or use `dev` for testing)
   - **Timeout**: Configure request timeout (default: 30s)
   - **Retry**: Configure retry attempts (default: 3)
4. **Click “Create”**

### Configuration example [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/sharing\#configuration-example)

PLAINTEXT

```nextra-code

ID: my-mcp-server
Server Type: HTTP/SSE
URL: https://abc123.ngrok-free.app
Secret: my-secure-secret-123
Timeout: 30s
Retry: 3
```

## Step 4: Test your MCP server [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/sharing\#step-4-test-your-mcp-server)

Verify that your server is accessible and working correctly.

### Using the Arcade Playground [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/sharing\#using-the-arcade-playground)

1. **Go to the Arcade Playground**
2. **Select your MCP server** from the dropdown
3. **Choose a tool** from your server
4. **Execute the tool** with test parameters
5. **Verify the response:**
   - Check that the response is correct
   - View request logs in your local server terminal
   - Inspect the tunnel dashboard for request details

Last updated onOctober 11, 2025

[Transports](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports "Transports") [Server](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/server "Server")

## Arcade API Reference
[Skip to Content](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references#nextra-skip-nav)

# API Reference

Complete reference documentation for Arcade's APIs and SDKs.

### API

Arcade's REST API is for orchestrating tools, managing authentication, and controlling agent workflows at runtime. Use this API to integrate Arcade's tool execution and permission management into your agent applications.

[View API Reference](https://docs.arcade.dev/references/api)

### Arcade MCP (MCP Server SDK)

Arcade MCP provides a FastAPI-like interface for building custom Model Context Protocol servers. Use this SDK to create your own tools and expose them through the standardized MCP protocol.

[View SDK Reference](https://docs.arcade.dev/references/mcp/python/overview)

### Arcade Clients

Arcade provides clients for several languages. These clients make it easy to use Arcade's tools within your agents and applications.

#### Python Client

Install with:

`pip install arcadepy` [Learn more about the Python Client](https://github.com/ArcadeAI/arcade-py)

#### JavaScript / TypeScript Client

Install with:

`npm install @arcadeai/arcadejs` [Learn more about the JavaScript / TypeScript Client](https://github.com/ArcadeAI/arcade-js)

#### Go Client

Install with:

`go get -u 'github.com/ArcadeAI/arcade-go'` [Learn more about the Go Client](https://github.com/ArcadeAI/arcade-go)

Note: MCP-compatible versions of these clients are in development and will be documented soon.

## MCP Python Transports
[Skip to Content](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports#nextra-skip-nav)

[Reference](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references "Reference") Arcade MCP [Python](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview "Python") Transports

Copy page

# Transport Modes

MCP servers can communicate with clients through different transport mechanisms. Each transport is optimized for specific use cases and client types.

## stdio Transport [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#stdio-transport)

The stdio (standard input/output) transport is used for direct client connections.

### Characteristics [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#characteristics)

- Communicates via standard input/output streams
- Logs go to stderr to avoid interfering with protocol messages
- Ideal for desktop applications and command-line tools
- Used by Claude Desktop and similar clients

### Usage [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#usage)

**Recommended: Using Arcade CLI**

Terminal

```nextra-code

# Run with stdio transport
uv run server.py stdio
```

**Alternative: Direct Python**

Python

```nextra-code

# Run your server directly
uv run server.py stdio

# Or with python
app.run(transport="stdio")
```

### Client Configuration [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#client-configuration)

For Claude Desktop, use the `arcade configure` command:

Terminal

```nextra-code

arcade configure claude --from-local
```

Or manually edit `~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`:

JSON

```nextra-code

{
    "mcpServers": {
        "my-tools": {
            "command": "arcade",
            "args": ["mcp", "stdio"],
            "cwd": "/path/to/your/tools"
        }
    }
}
```

## HTTP Transport [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#http-transport)

The HTTP transport provides REST/SSE endpoints for web-based clients.

### Characteristics [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#characteristics-1)

- RESTful API with Server-Sent Events (SSE) for streaming
- Supports hot reload for development
- Includes health checks and API documentation
- Can be deployed behind reverse proxies
- Suitable for web applications and services

### Usage [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#usage-1)

**Recommended: Using Arcade CLI**

Terminal

```nextra-code

# Run with HTTP transport (default)
uv run server.py
uv run server.py http
```

**Alternative: Direct Python**

Python

```nextra-code

# Run your server directly
uv run server.py

# Or with python
app.run(transport="http", host="0.0.0.0", port=8080)
```

### Endpoints [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#endpoints)

When running in HTTP mode, the server provides:

- `GET /health` \- Health check endpoint
- `GET /mcp` \- SSE endpoint for MCP protocol
- `GET /docs` \- Swagger UI documentation (debug mode)
- `GET /redoc` \- ReDoc documentation (debug mode)

### Development Features [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#development-features)

**With Arcade CLI:**

Python

```nextra-code

# Enable hot reload and debug mode
app.run(host="127.0.0.1", port=8000, reload=True)

# This enables:
# - Automatic restart on code changes
# - Detailed error messages
# - API documentation endpoints
# - Verbose logging
```

## Choosing a Transport [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#choosing-a-transport)

### Use stdio when: [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#use-stdio-when)

- Integrating with desktop applications (Claude Desktop, VS Code)
- Building command-line tools
- You need simple, direct communication
- Running in environments without network access

### Use HTTP when: [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#use-http-when)

- Building web applications
- Deploying to cloud environments
- You need to support multiple concurrent clients
- Integrating with existing web services
- You want API documentation and testing tools

## Transport Configuration [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#transport-configuration)

### Environment Variables [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#environment-variables)

Both transports respect common environment variables:

Terminal

```nextra-code

# Server identification
MCP_SERVER_NAME="My MCP Server"
MCP_SERVER_VERSION="1.0.0"

# Logging
MCP_DEBUG=true
MCP_LOG_LEVEL=DEBUG

# HTTP-specific
MCP_HTTP_HOST=0.0.0.0
MCP_HTTP_PORT=8080
```

### Programmatic Configuration [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#programmatic-configuration)

When using MCPApp:

Python

```nextra-code

from arcade_mcp_server import MCPApp

app = MCPApp(
    name="my-server",
    version="1.0.0",
    log_level="DEBUG"
)

# Run with specific transport
if __name__ == "__main__":
    import sys

    if len(sys.argv) > 1 and sys.argv[1] == "stdio":
        app.run(transport="stdio")
    else:
        app.run(transport="http", host="0.0.0.0", port=8080)
```

## Security Considerations [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#security-considerations)

### stdio Transport [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#stdio-transport-1)

- Inherits security context of the parent process
- No network exposure
- Suitable for trusted environments

### HTTP Transport [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#http-transport-1)

- Exposes network endpoints
- Should use authentication in production
- Consider using HTTPS with reverse proxy
- Implement rate limiting for public deployments

## Advanced Transport Features [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#advanced-transport-features)

### Custom Middleware (HTTP) [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#custom-middleware-http)

Add custom middleware to HTTP transports:

Python

```nextra-code

from arcade_mcp_server import MCPApp

app = MCPApp(name="my-server")

# Add custom middleware
@app.middleware("http")
async def add_custom_headers(request, call_next):
    response = await call_next(request)
    response.headers["X-Custom-Header"] = "value"
    return response
```

### Transport Events [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/transports\#transport-events)

Listen to transport lifecycle events:

Python

```nextra-code

@app.on_event("startup")
async def startup_handler():
    print("Server starting up...")

@app.on_event("shutdown")
async def shutdown_handler():
    print("Server shutting down...")
```

Last updated onOctober 11, 2025

## MCP Python Types
[Skip to Content](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/types#nextra-skip-nav)

[Reference](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references "Reference") Arcade MCP [Python](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/overview "Python") Types

Copy page

# Types

Core Pydantic models and enums for the MCP protocol shapes.

## `arcade_mcp_server.types` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/types\#arcade_mcp_servertypes)

### `CallToolResult` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/types\#calltoolresult)

**Bases:** `Result`

A list of content objects that represent the unstructured result of the tool call.

#### `content` (instance-attribute) [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/types\#content-instance-attribute)

An optional JSON object that represents the structured result of the tool call.

### `SessionMessage` [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/types\#sessionmessage)

**Type:** dataclass

Wrapper for messages in transport sessions.

## Examples [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/types\#examples)

### Constructing a JSON-RPC request and response model [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/types\#constructing-a-json-rpc-request-and-response-model)

Python

```nextra-code

from arcade_mcp_server.types import JSONRPCRequest, JSONRPCResponse

req = JSONRPCRequest(id=1, method="ping", params={})
res = JSONRPCResponse(id=req.id, result={})
print(req.model_dump_json())
print(res.model_dump_json())
```

### Building a tools/call request and examining result shape [Permalink for this section](https://docs.arcade.dev/en/references/mcp/python/types\#building-a-toolscall-request-and-examining-result-shape)

Python

```nextra-code

from arcade_mcp_server.types import CallToolRequest, CallToolResult, TextContent

call = CallToolRequest(
    id=2,
    method="tools/call",
    params={
        "name": "Toolkit.tool",
        "arguments": {"text": "hello"},
    },
)
# Result would typically be produced by the server:
result = CallToolResult(
    content=[TextContent(type="text", text="Echo: hello")],
    structuredContent={"result": "Echo: hello"},
    isError=False
)
```
